item.title: Trump Says His Unpredictable Style Gives Him Leverage. But It Has a Cost.
item.description: A year into President Trump’s second term, his threats, retreats, twists and turns appear to be wearing on allies and adversaries.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump on Tuesday. White House officials say his negotiating style has yielded results, pointing to new trade deals and peace deals.

item.title: China’s Xi Presses Trump on Taiwan in Phone Call
item.description: Both leaders gave versions of what they discussed, but the Chinese president’s take made clear the issue of the island was front and center.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and President Xi Jinping of China in South Korea in October.

item.title: Trump Administration Is Delaying Hundreds of Wind and Solar Projects
item.description: Federal agencies are delaying approvals for renewable energy projects on both federal land and private property at a time when electricity demand is going up.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Simon Simard for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration has been halting or delaying federal approvals that were once seen as routine.

item.title: Supreme Court Clears Way for California Voting Map
item.description: The state’s Republican Party had asked the justices to step in and block the new congressional maps, which give an advantage to Democrats, before the midterms.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sorting ballots at a processing center in City of Industry, Calif., after the special election in November that asked the state’s voters to approve a new congressional map.

item.title: Brad Karp Resigns as Paul Weiss Chairman Amid Epstein Fallout
item.description: The decision followed the release of a series of embarrassing emails between Mr. Karp and Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein, Michael S. Schmidt and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
item.media:credit: Carly Zavala for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Recent reporting has created a distraction and has placed a focus on me that is not in the best interests of the firm,” Brad Karp said in a statement from Paul Weiss.

item.title: ‘My Crazy Friend’: The Royals Who Stayed Close to Epstein
item.description: Emails, texts, photos and videos show how Jeffrey Epstein, even after becoming a convicted sex offender, burnished his ties to royal family members from several countries and their advisers.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Lise Aserud/NTB, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Crown Princess Mette-Marit of Norway at an event in Oslo in 2024.

item.title: Files Reveal Epstein’s Money Mingled with Silicon Valley’s Tech Start-Ups
item.description: The disgraced financier regularly courted tech industry figures not just for their prestige but also for access to promising companies.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Erin Griffith and Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Department of Justice, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Last week’s disclosures of Jeffrey Epstein’s communications offer insight into how he made his money as an investor after his 2008 conviction.

item.title: In Forcing the Clintons to Testify on Epstein, Comer Sets a New Precedent
item.description: The Republican chairman’s successful targeting of a former president who faces no charge of wrongdoing was the sort of tactic typical in an autocracy where leaders fear being jailed when they are out of power.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative James R. Comer of Kentucky, at the Capitol on Tuesday, had been trying for months to get Bill and Hillary Clinton to testify in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

item.title: Savannah Guthrie Addresses Mother’s Abductor: ‘We Are Ready to Talk’
item.description: Ms. Guthrie, the television anchor, and her siblings released a video on Wednesday night asking for proof that their mother, Nancy, is alive.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Reis Thebault

item.title: Savannah Guthrie’s Missing Mother Has Nation Fixated on an Arizona Subdivision
item.description: The disappearance of Nancy Guthrie, mother of the news anchor Savannah Guthrie, has reporters, neighbors and drones flooding streets and foothills in Tucson, Ariz.
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault
item.media:credit: Jan Sonnenmair/Getty Images
item.media:description: Nancy Guthrie’s home became a focus for the fascination of neighbors and the nation alike.

item.title: Trump Says He Ordered Withdrawal of 700 Immigration Agents From Minneapolis
item.description: About 2,000 personnel will be left in Minnesota, where President Trump’s immigration crackdown has generated outrage.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo and Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump said his administration’s approach would continue to be “tough” and he urged local officials to cooperate with federal immigration officers.

item.title: Prosecutor Fired After Voicing Frustration With Immigration Caseload
item.description: The prosecutor, Julie T. Le, told a judge that she and her colleagues in the U.S. attorney’s office were overwhelmed by the White House’s immigration operation in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Glenn Thrush and Hamed Aleaziz
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents arrest an individual in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: Residents of Cortina, a Winter Olympics Hub, Are Angry About All the Construction
item.description: In Cortina d’Ampezzo, a hub for the Games in northern Italy, some residents, including a former Olympian, are annoyed about all the construction. Others are annoyed that they’re annoyed.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Josephine de La Bruyère
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laborers in Cortina d’Ampezzo working in January to finish a ski lift before the Winter Games begin.

item.title: Canada’s Tate McRae Roots for Team USA in New Olympics Ad
item.description: Tate McRae’s promotional video for NBC, in which she name checks Team USA athletes, has drawn the ire of some Canadians as the country’s relationship with the United States hits new lows.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Monica Schipper/Getty Images
item.media:description: Tate McRae in December in Los Angeles.

item.title: Nike, Accused of Bias Against White Workers, Is Under Federal Investigation
item.description: It appeared to be the first time the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has targeted diversity policies at a large company.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien and Kim Bhasin
item.media:credit: Tingshu Wang/Reuters
item.media:description: Nike has sponsorship partnerships with world-famous athletes including LeBron James and Caitlin Clark.

item.title: Doctors’ Group Endorses Restrictions on Gender-Related Surgery for Minors
item.description: The A.M.A.’s announcement followed a similar recommendation from the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. Other medical groups argued for a more personalized approach.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.category: World Professional Association for Transgender Health
item.media:credit: Jim West/Alamy
item.media:description: Two major medical organizations have now endorsed age limits on gender-related surgery for teenagers struggling with gender dysphoria.

item.title: Washington Post Cuts More Than 300 Jobs
item.description: The layoffs cut into The Post’s local, international and sports coverage, and reduced its entire work force by about 30 percent.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin, Katie Robertson and Erik Wemple
item.media:credit: Annabelle Gordon/Reuters
item.media:description: Matt Murray, executive editor of The Washington Post, told employees that the revamped paper would focus more on national news and politics, and business and health, and less on other areas.

item.title: The Washington Post Eliminates Its Sports Department
item.description: The Post is laying off or reassigning all the reporters and editors in its sports section, days before the Super Bowl and the Winter Olympics in Italy.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Washington Post leadership announced major layoffs within the newsroom.

item.title: How Universities and States Are Increasing Surveillance of Professors
item.description: Scrutiny of university classrooms is being formalized, with new laws requiring professors to post syllabuses and tip lines for students to complain.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Texas and elsewhere, professors must share their syllabuses online. Some faculty members worry about censorship.

item.title: Venezuela Said to Detain Maduro Allies Targeted by the U.S.
item.description: The questioning of the politically connected businessmen, Raúl Gorrín and Alex Saab, signaled deepening cooperation between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Annie Correal

item.title: Stellan Skarsgard on ‘Sentimental Value’ and His Wide-Ranging Career
item.description: After a stroke four years ago, the actor has changed how he approaches performances, including the one he’s become an awards favorite for.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan and Jason Nocito
item.media:credit: Jason Nocito for The New York Times

item.title: Two Quit Human Rights Watch Over Shelved Report Criticizing Israel
item.description: Omar Shakir and Milena Ansari said they had quit over the stalled publication of a report that concludes it is a crime against humanity to deny Palestinians the ability to return to the territory that is now Israel.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Jerusalem in 2021.

item.title: Mamdani Chooses a Liberal Jewish Leader to Run Antisemitism Office
item.description: Phylisa Wisdom, the executive director of the New York Jewish Agenda, shares Mayor Zohran Mamdani’s criticism of Israel’s treatment of Gaza, but supports its right to exist as a Jewish state.
item.dc:creator: Sally Goldenberg and Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: Kent J. Edwards for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani pledged to keep the Office to Combat Antisemitism, which was created by his predecessor, Eric Adams.

item.title: New York City Partners with W.H.O. as U.S. Withdraws From Global Effort
item.description: City health authorities are joining a network that counters new pathogens and emerging outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein
item.media:credit: Robert Hradil/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Trump administration withdrew the United States from the World Health Organization in January.

item.title: New York and New Jersey Resolve Fight Over Port Authority Control
item.description: The board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will vote this week to confirm Kathryn Garcia as the executive director and Jean Roehrenbeck as the deputy executive director of the agency.
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGeehan
item.category: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
item.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times; James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: New York Governor Kathy Hochul and New Jersey Governor Mikie Sherrill each nominated an executive director to lead the Port Authority.

item.title: Bright Horizons Child Care Centers Face Dozens of Alarming Complaints
item.description: In New York City, health officials have moved to shut down one center where workers were charged with child abuse. Records show that problems extend across the network.
item.dc:creator: Ed Shanahan
item.category: Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings (NYC)
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: At a Bright Horizons center near Columbus Circle in Manhattan, workers were accused of taping a child’s mouth shut and putting a bleach solution in children’s water bottles.

item.title: How Much Longer Can Mexico Walk Trump’s Tightrope?
item.description: Trump wants total war on Mexico’s cartels. Sheinbaum won’t give it to him.
item.dc:creator: Mary Beth Sheridan
item.media:credit: Guillermo Arias/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: This Is the Real Reason Susie Wiles Talked to Me 11 Times
item.description: What did her unguarded remarks reveal about the Trump White House?
item.dc:creator: Chris Whipple
item.media:credit: Brendan Smialowski/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Have You Been Impacted by the Affordability Crisis? Tell Us.
item.description: We want to hear about how costs are having an impact on your life.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times
item.media:description: A child-care center in Brooklyn, N.Y.

item.title: Nigeria Attack Leaves More Than 160 Dead
item.description: The raiders stormed a rural community in central Nigeria, killing dozens and setting homes on fire in one of the country’s worst recent attacks.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Ismail Auwal and Saikou Jammeh

item.title: Dutch Queen Joins the Military
item.description: Queen Máxima of the Netherlands enlisted as a reservist, the Royal House said, because the country’s security “can no longer be taken for granted.”
item.dc:creator: Koba Ryckewaert
item.media:credit: Dutch Ministry of Defense
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Royal House showing Queen Máxima of the Netherlands during military training in Breda on Wednesday.

item.title: Blanche Marvin, 100, Dies; Critic Was, Maybe, ‘Streetcar’ Inspiration
item.description: She was a ubiquitous presence at London theaters and claimed to have inspired the name — and final words — of Tennessee Williams’s Blanche DuBois.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
